p: Recent studies have shown that Ae. aegypti transinfected with Wolbachia are able to reduce the replication and transmission of DENV and CHIKV[ 11â€“ 14]. The aim of the control strategy is to introduce Wolbachia into wild Ae. aegypti populations by deliberately releasing both males and females Wolbachia-infected Ae. aegypt [ 15, 16]. The ability of Wolbachia to manipulate mosquito reproduction using cytoplasmic incompatibility (CI) and its mode of transmission have provided the bacterium with a reproductive advantage, thus ensuring its spread into uninfected wild Ae. aegypti populations [ 9, 16].
